threads.author: .anotherandrew
threads.content: contention window -- clients must wait a minimum amount of time before attempting a rebroadcast, where routers/repeaters don't have that minimum time. So if you have a router/repeater that has no business being either of those roles, it can "kill" an area of the mesh because all the clients (including better placed ones) will hear the rebroadcast and cancel their pending retransmit

threads.author: .anotherandrew
threads.content: `ROUTER_LATE` pretty much does the exact same thing but without the heuristic of trying to detect a quick-to-rebroadcast node. `ROUTER_LATE` will simply wait the maximum CW time and rebroadcast, regardless of whether it heard another node rebroadcast the packet or not.

In all other circumstances, keep the existing key-mismatch behaviour.

threads.author: jamon1
threads.content: https://meshtastic.org/docs/overview/mesh-algo/ is the closest thing I've found to what you're probably looking for.  covers the high level protocol/mechanisms.  when you dig into the protobufs, the most confusing bit to get past is that the main payload referenced in that doc is a "Data" object in the protobufs, which has a PortNum Enum and a few other high level fields, and another payload.  The inner payload will be one of the other protobufs, based on the PortNum.  They are mostly self explanatory, other than NodeInfo being a "User" type.

threads.author: jamon1
threads.content: the logic for rebroadcasting packets is a bit more complex/confusing.  it depends on the role, the port, the priority of the packet, how many hops it's already traveled, I think maybe it depends on the RSSi of the message you're repeating too... channel utilization, and some random

threads.author: jamon1
threads.content: and I'm probably missing some things... I've just started gathering information on that

threads.author: jamon1
threads.content: the biggest "issues" (I quote issues here because I don't know the developers' position on the project goals) in the vein of encryption/pki that I've seen (I'm admittedly rather new to the firmware though) is that channels are all symmetrical encryption with no signing, so anyone can spoof anything in a channel that they have the key for... or overwhelm the network with spam, easily

We‚Äôre a company based in India, currently working on a large-scale deployment project (government project) involving around 500 nodes. Due to client requirements, we are using a custom hardware platform based on **AT32 microcontroller + SX1262 LoRa module** instead of the commonly used RAK4630.

4. Any considerations or known limitations we should be aware of while working with SX1262 on non-standard platforms.

We‚Äôre comfortable handling the hardware-specific development but would appreciate any help, suggestions, or documentation pointers from the community to ensure we go about this the right way.

threads.content: the v3 charging circuit is pretty basic and the chip on the back gets hot. For every node I can, I use an external charge controller board to better protect the battery, improve charging efficiency (especially form solar), and avoid the worrying (to me anyway) hotspot chip on the back of the board.

threads.author: prosthetichead2869
threads.content: Niche, but cool: if you can point a 'compass' at another node reliably, you could also point a steerable directional antenna...

threads.author: prosthetichead2869
threads.content: Have tried a whole bunch of things, from <$1 aliexpress boards for basic USB / solar, up to quite complex custom jobs. Honestly almost anything with the right voltage and current params will solve the basic 'charge the LiPo faster and don't overheat' issue. I do a lot of messing about with energy storage that isn't ~3.7v Li (LFP, LTO, EDLCs), as I don't like short lifespan, safety profile, toxic and rare elements, etc of 'standard' lithium chemistries. If what you want is simply a better charger for LiPo you can get something with a USB, 1A output for about $0.8.

threads.author: prosthetichead2869
threads.content: I don't have those particular boards, but others based on TP4056 chip that are fine for charging any ~3.7v cell (LiPo, LNO, LCO, LMO and the verious other mixed Li-ion cells) - basically they should stop charging at 4.2V to avoid overcharging and your cells need to be able to handle 1A charging current - any LiPo >1000mAH should be ok.

threads.author: prosthetichead2869
threads.content: I see that a lot with cheap devices with USB-C - hence I still keep a bunch of USB A --> C cables about

threads.author: prosthetichead2869
threads.content: it's either to save the ~$0.001 / board or it's sloppyness that's not worth correcting later - often the USB-C boards are identical to older micro or even mini USB ones except the physical connector. One of the Raspberry Pi versions made this mistake (they corrected it later) - I have one, it will only work with high current 5V supplies that don't require a PD / PPS trigger which is a little annoying.

threads.author: prosthetichead2869
threads.content: My guess is RPi make / rebrand their own USB-C charger that was also technically not correctly behaved (VBUS-hot) - just dumps 5V up to 3A if I remember correctly. If they were using that then the issue doesn't show - should have course still have picked it up before release. To be fair to them, USB-C was only just taking over from microUSB and a whole collection of proprietary connectors and there were a lot of 5v only USB-C chargers on the market.

threads.author: prosthetichead2869
threads.content: I do have a bunch of USB-C PD/PPS trigger boards from AliExpress too, so can always use one of those as a fix or just as a connector when making custom stuff.

OK, to answer your questions:
1) The feature is not being removed as such - the new UI has different controls and actions to trigger those controls. The double-tap to send position/node-info will be replaced with that option elsewhere, as the UI develops.
2) There are ways to tweak the firmware to adjust the rate limits for various actions. I'm not going to link you to how to do it.

With regards to your use case, you've explained that:
> I'm working up here on a tower and trying to optimize aiming antennas or evaluating a path NOT on any main or being used mesh. On its own dedicated frequency away from any populated mesh.
> I'm also at other times on a building top needing to test an RF path between building sites with dynamically changing on air noise and need to be able to check the RF path quickly and multiple times while testing under varying conditions that change quickly.

The function you are using to perform these tests is not intended for that purpose. There are other tools for the task that you are doing that do not require modification of the firmware. If you have access to the other end (the one that you are evaluating the path to) then range-test is able to be set remotely, and the pings can be evaluated for signal strength as they arrive. If the other node is more than 1 hop away, traceroute is a more appropriate tool.

If you feel there is a tool or function that would be better than these, please suggest it.

What I mean by the ephemeral nature is that it's an inherently transient system - the mesh flexes and shifts with the movement of the nodes and the prevailing RF conditions. In addition, in every app and on every platform there is a strong bias towards discarding the messages, sometimes shortly after receiving them.
For users and the system, it's important to have good feedback in the system and an understanding of what implicit ack and explicit ack are, but the messaging overhead from a persistent connection is too much.

> **Single reception mode**
> At the end of the payload, the RxDone interrupt is generated together with the interrupt PayloadCrcError if the payload CRC is not valid. However, even when the  RC is not valid, the data are written in the FIFO data buffer for post processing. Following the RxDone interrupt the radio goes to Standby mode.

> **In continuous mode** the received packet processing sequence is given below.
> 1 Whilst in Sleep or Standby mode select RXCONT mode.
> 2 Upon reception of a valid header CRC the RxDone interrupt is set. The radio remains in RXCONT mode waiting for the next RX LoRaTM packet.
> 3 The PayloadCrcError flag should be checked for packet integrity.
> 4 If packet has been correctly received the FIFO data buffer can be read (see below).
> 5 The reception process (steps 2 - 4) can be repeated or receiver operating mode exited as desired.

threads.author: __pfizer

> Why should I need to learn to compile firmware to configure this power setting, but can turn on ham mode by checking a box?

For the same reason the firmware on the motherboard of your home computer doesn't give you a direct override of how much power will be allowed onto the traces. 

It's to ensure the guaranteed operability of the consumer electronics people are paying for. You are welcome to change it, but as a consumer as well as a developer i'd expect that it's unlikely something like that would end up in the main distribution.

threads.author: actuallyryank
threads.content:
If you've used BIOS firmware on motherboards you'd know they absolutely allow you to pump crazy unsafe voltages into your hardware.  

This change is similar to a BIOS developer saying "you never have any reason to run more than 1.2v to your CPU, because efficiency!!" when those of us who power our computers and homes on solar power, who dont have an environmental issue, can safely run 1.4v and get higher clock speeds to save us time compressing video files.   To lock it to 1.2v would be ignorant.

Probably a poor analogy anyway, because I dont think the devs are trying to prevent us from using our hardware (at least I hope not!) and are more concerned about getting in trouble with the FCC.
